content: There is a small typo at "Therefor 'did' is not changed", Therefor meant to be Therefore.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good easy-ish medium puzzle.
I like it.  I'd like it better if the Statement part explicitly said that spaces and punctuation were to be preserved and/or one of the first couple of test cases included punctuation.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Took about 30 minutes to write an independent solution.  Looking afterwards it appears shockingly similar to author provided solution :D

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It seems interesting and fun problem.
Just a very small point, you explain twice how to correct 'itt', but the text actually contains 'iit'

I like the concept a lot.  The test cases will need to be carefully constructed (and they appear to be good).  

Possible hazards in test case creation:
* correctly spelled words that have repeating letters
* near-neighbour words that are spelled correctly (e.g. all, mall, small, dismal)
* punctuation inside words (e.g. don't, o'clock)

I rated it as "Difficulty: Medium" because it is more complicated than a loop, if/else plus one array.  Although you can argue that it can be done with just an array and a few loops, using a dictionary and two passes through the data is most likely the appropriate approach.  This is certainly harder than "The Descent" and "monday tuesday happy days"

My rules of thumb for difficulty is as follows : 
* if/else and possibly a loop is 'easy'.  
* Recursion, DFS, BFS, Minimax is 'medium'.  
* Tricky or mathy stuff with multiple steps is 'hard' or 'very hard'
punctuation is not allowed inside a word.   According to the constraints "Only correct words that are lower case ascii characters from a-z"
Thanks.  Fixed.  I found another type in the constraints.
Thanks, that is a good point
Done.  I've added a bold comment in the description and added it to the 3 test/validation

That's about it, except that "none letters" looks like it should be non-letters or maybe just nonletters.  Is that an autocorrect?

One extra tidbit from the reference solution: You can combine F-strings with the R or r "raw string" (aka "regex" string) to get something like fr'\w{old}\w' and not have to double the backslashes.
i caught the none letters mistake just seconds before your reply.  Good catch.  I didn't know about the r for raw string.  I like it.

I've checked over the hazards, thanks.  Effort was put into careful construction and the test and validation cases have been double checked.

The only vocabulary that is to be used is what is in the text, so the cases are easily controlled.  The examples (all, mall, small, ...) would be a problem if those words were in the given text.  I'll add a note in the description that words not in the given text are not to be used.
